Hardware Architecture Simulation
Project Overview
MIPS is a instruction set architecture. I made a simulator which takes a file containing MIPS instructions and executes them. This was made in C++.
The main goal of this was to get a better understanding of hardware architecture and instruction sets. Later parts of the project was focussed on hardware optimization. Pipelining, Parallel programming, cache and DRAM implementation, forwarding/reordering of instructions, lookaheads etc were implemented one after another to make the simulator as close to real processors as possible.
Go Back
Place- College
Time of Work
This was a month long project. Time was almost equally distributed among all the features implemented.
Reordering/forwarding and improving DRAM throughput was the most time consuming process. Another time consuming process was implementing the basic MIPS simulator to handle all possible instructions.
Go Back
Major Challenge: Improving Throughput and Pipelining
Resources Used and Skills Learnt
Some MIPS documentation and Qtspim was used to get familiar with the instruction set.
Implementation into a simulator was done without any external help. Skill set acquired was a better understanding og how CPUs work, how they are designed and what tradeoffs are considered. Extensive knowledge of cache and DRAM was acquired through this project.
